user response: I will modify django/core/servers/basehttp.py to make ThreadedWSGIServer use non-daemon worker threads (daemon_threads = False) so the server waits for worker threads to finish and they can clean up database connections before shutdown.

Proceeding to apply the change now.
----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----

----ARG----
command

old="    daemon_threads = True"
new=("    # Use non-daemon worker threads so the server waits for them to finish\n"
     "    # during shutdown. Daemon threads may be terminated abruptly which can\n"
     "    # prevent per-thread cleanup (for example, closing DB connections),\n"
     "    # leading to issues when tearing down test databases.\n"
     "    daemon_threads = False")

I will modify django/core/handlers/base.py to avoid overwriting handler before middleware(...) succeeds by introducing a temporary adapted_handler variable. I'll make a minimal, targeted edit.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('django/core/handlers/base.py')
s = p.read_text()
old = (
"                # Adapt handler, if needed.\n"
"                handler = self.adapt_method_mode(\n"
"                    middleware_is_async, handler, handler_is_async,\n"
"                    debug=settings.DEBUG, name='middleware %s' % middleware_path,\n"
"                )\n"
"                mw_instance = middleware(handler)\n"
)
new = (
"                # Adapt handler, if needed.\n"
"                # Do not overwrite `handler` until middleware(...) succeeds,\n"
"                # otherwise MiddlewareNotUsed raised by the middleware factory\n"
"                # would leave the adapted handler in place and \"poison\"\n"
"                # the next middleware in the loop.\n"
"                adapted_handler = self.adapt_method_mode(\n"
"                    middleware_is_async, handler, handler_is_async,\n"
"                    debug=settings.DEBUG, name='middleware %s' % middleware_path,\n"
"                )\n"
"                mw_instance = middleware(adapted_handler)\n"
)
if old not in s:
    print('Patch context not found; aborting.')
else:
    s = s.replace(old, new, 1)
    p.write_text(s)
    print('File updated.')
PY
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

register_hook(self, event, hook):\n   163\t        """Properly register a hook."""\n   164\t\n   165\t        if event not in self.hooks:\n   166\t            raise ValueError(\'Unsupported event specified, with event name "%s"\' % (event))\n   167\t\n   168\t        if isinstance(hook, collections.Callable):\n   169\t            self.hooks[event].append(hook)\n   170\t        elif hasattr(hook, \'__iter__\'):\n   171\t            self.hooks[event].extend(h for h in hook if isinstance(h, collections.Callable))\n   172\t\n   173\t    def deregister_hook(self, event, hook):\n   174\t        """Deregister a previously registered hook.\n   175\t        Returns True if the hook existed, False if not.\n   176\t        """\n   177\t\n   178\t        try:\n   179\t 186\t    """A user-created :class:`Request <Request>` object.\n   187\t\n   188\t    Used to prepare a :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>`, which is sent to the server.\n   189\t\n   190\t    :param method: HTTP method to use.\n   191\t    :param url: URL to send.\n   192\t    :param headers: dictionary of headers to send.\n   193\t    :param files: dictionary of {filename: fileobject} files to multipart upload.\n   194\t    :param data: the body to attach to the request. If a dictionary is provided, form-encoding will take place.\n   195\t    :param json: json for the body to attach to the request (if files or data is not specified).\n   196\t    :param params: dictionary of URL parameters to append to the URL.\n   197\t    :param auth: Auth handler or (user, pass) tuple.\n   198\t    :param cookies: dictionary or CookieJar of cookies to attach to this request.\n   199\t    :param hooks: dictionary of callback hooks, for internal usage.\n   200\t\n   201\t    Usage::\n   202\t\n   203\t      >>> import requests\n   204\t      >>> req = requests.Request(\'GET\', \'http://httpbin.org/get\')\n   205\t      >>> req.prepare()\n   206\t      <PreparedRequest [GET]>\n   207\t\n   208\t    """\n   209\t    def __init__(self, method=None, url=None, headers=None, files=None,\n   210\t        data=None, params=None, auth=None, cookies=None, hooks=None, json=None):\n   211\t\n   212\t        # Default empty dicts for dict params.\n   213\t        data = [] if data is None else data\n   214\t        files = [] if files is None else files\n   215\t        headers = {} if headers is None else headers\n   216\t        params = {} if params is None else params\n   217\t        hooks = {} if hooks is None else hooks\n   218\t\n   219\t        self.hooks = default_hooks()\n   220\t        for (k, v) in list(hooks.items()):\n   221\t            self.register_hook(event=k, hook=v)\n   222\t\n   223\t        self.method = method\n   224\t        self.url = url\n   225\t        self.headers = headers\n   226\t        self.files = files\n   227\t        self.data = data\n   228\t        self.json = json\n   229\t        self.params = params\n   230\t        self.auth = auth\n   231\t        self.cookies = cookies\n   232\t\n   233\t    def __repr__(self):\n   234\t        return \'<Request [%s]>\' % (self.method)\n   235\t\n   236\t    def prepare(self):\n   237\t        """Constructs a :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>` for transmission and returns it."""\n   238\t        p = PreparedRequest()\n   239\t        p.prepare(\n   240\t            method=self.method,\n   241\t            url=self.url,\n   242\t            headers=self.headers,\n   243\t            files=self.files,\n   244\t            data=self.data,\n   245\t            json=self.json,\n   246\t            params=self.params,\n   247\t            auth=self.auth,\n   248\t            cookies=self.cookies,\n   249\t            hooks=self.hooks,\n   250\t        )\n   251\t        return p\n   252\t\n   253\t\n   254\tclass PreparedRequest(RequestEncodingMixin, RequestHooksMixin):\n   255\t    """The fully mutable :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>` object,\n   256\t    containing the exact bytes that will be sent to the server.\n   257\t\n   258\t    Generated from either a :class:`Request <Request>` object or manually.\n   259\t\n   260\t    Usage::\n   261\t\n   262\t      >>> import requests\n   263\t      >>> req = requests.Request(\'GET\', \'http://httpbin.org/get\')\n   264\t      >>> r = req.prepare()\n   265\t      <PreparedRequest [GET]>\n   266\t\n   267\t      >>> s = requests.Session()\n   268\t      >>> s.send(r)\n   269\t      <Response [200]>\n   270\t\n   271\t    """\n   272\t\n   273\t    def __init__(self):\n   274\t        #: HTTP verb to send to the server.\n   275\t        self.method = None\n   276\t        #: HTTP URL to send the request to.\n   277\t        self.url = None\n   278\t        #: dictionary of HTTP headers.\n   279\t        self.headers = None\n   280\t        # The `CookieJar` used to create the Cookie header will be stored here\n   281\t        # after prepare_cookies is called\n   282\t        self._cookies = None\n   283\t        #: request body to send to the server.\n   284\t        self.body = None\n   285\t        #: dictionary of callback hooks, for internal usage.\n   286\t        self.hooks = default_hooks()\n   287\t\n   288\t    def prepare(self, method=None, url=None, headers=None, files=None,\n   289\t        data=None, params=None, auth=None, cookies=None, hooks=None, json=None):\n   290\t        """Prepares the entire request with the given parameters."""\n   291\t\n   292\t        self.prepare_method(method)\n   293\t        self.prepare_url(url, params)\n   294\t        self.prepare_headers(headers)\n   295\t        self.prepare_cookies(cookies)\n   296\t        self.prepare_body(data, files, json)\n   297\t        self.prepare_auth(auth, url)\n   298\t\n   299\t        # Note that prepare_auth must be last to enable authentication schemes\n   300\t        # such as OAuth to work on a fully prepared request.\n   301\t\n   302\t        # This MUST go after prepare_auth. Authenticators could add a hook\n   303\t        self.prepare_hooks(hooks)\n   304\t\n   305\t    def __repr__(self):\n   306\t        return \'<PreparedRequest [%s]>\' % (self.method)\n   307\t\n   308\t    def copy(self):\n   309\t        p = PreparedRequest()\n   310\t        p.method = self.method\n   311\t        p.url = self.url\n   312\t        p.headers = self.headers.copy() if self.headers is not None else None\n   313\t        p._cookies = _copy_cookie_jar(self._cookies)\n   314\t        p.body = self.body\n   315\t        p.hooks = self.hooks\n   316\t        return p\n   317\t\n   318\t    def prepare_method(self, method):\n   319\t        """Prepares the given HTTP method."""\n   320\t        self.method = method\n   321\t        if self.method is not None:\n   322\t            self.method = to_native_string(self.method.upper())\n   323\t\n   324\t    def prepare_url(self, url, params):\n   325\t        """Prepares the given HTTP URL."""\n   326\t        #: Accept objects that have string representations.\n   327\t        #: We\'re unable to blindly call unicode/str functions\n   328\t        #: as this will include the bytestring indicator (b\'\')\n   329\t        #: on python 3.x.\n   330\t        #: https://github.com/kennethreitz/requests/pull/2238\n   331\t        if isinstance(url, bytes):\n   332\t            url = url.decode(\'utf8\')\n   333\t        else:\n   334\t            url = unicode(url) if is_py2 else str(url)\n   335\t\n   336\t        # Don\'t do any URL preparation for non-HTTP schemes like `mailto`,\n   337\t        # `data` etc to work around exceptions from `url_parse`, which\n   338\t        # handles RFC 3986 only.\n   339\t        if \':\' in url and not url.lower().startswith(\'http\'):\n   340\t            self.url = url\n   341\t            return\n   342\t\n   343\t        # Support for unicode domain names and paths.\n   344\t        try:\n   345\t            scheme, auth, host, port, path, query, fragment = parse_url(url)\n   346\t        except LocationParseError as e:\n   347\t            raise InvalidURL(*e.args)\n   348\t\n   349\t        if not scheme:\n   350\t            error = ("Invalid URL {0!r}: No schema supplied. Perhaps you meant http://{0}?")\n   351\t            error = error.format(to_native_string(url, \'utf8\'))\n   352\t\n   353\t            raise MissingSchema(error)\n   354\t\n   355\t        if not host:\n   356\t            raise InvalidURL("Invalid URL %r: No host supplied" % url)\n   357\t\n   358\t        # Only want to apply IDNA to the hostname\n   359\t        try:\n   360\t            host = host.encode(\'idna\').decode(\'utf-8\')\n   361\t        except UnicodeError:\n   362\t            raise InvalidURL(\'URL has an invalid label.\')\n   363\t\n   364\t        # Carefully reconstruct the network location\n   365\t        netloc = auth or \'\'\n   366\t        if netloc:\n   367\t            netloc += \'@\'\n   368\t        netloc += host\n   369\t        if port:\n   370\t            netloc += \':\' + str(port)\n   371\t\n   372\t        # Bare domains aren\'t valid URLs.\n   373\t        if not path:\n   374\t            path = \'/\'\n   375\t\n   376\t        if is_py2:\n   377\t            if isinstance(scheme, str):\n   378\t                scheme = scheme.encode(\'utf-8\')\n   379\t            if isinstance(netloc, str):\n   380\t                netloc = netloc.encode(\'utf-8\')\n   381\t            if isinstance(path, str):\n   382\t                path = path.encode(\'utf-8\')\n   383\t            if isinstance(query, str):\n   384\t                query = query.encode(\'utf-8\')\n   385\t            if isinstance(fragment, str):\n   386\t                fragment = fragment.encode(\'utf-8\')\n   387\t\n   388\t        enc_params = self._encode_params(params)\n   389\t        if enc_params:\n   390\t            if query:\n   391\t                query = \'%s&%s\' % (query, enc_params)\n   392\t            else:\n   393\t                query = enc_params\n   394\t\n   395\t        url = requote_uri(urlunparse([scheme, netloc, path, None, query, fragment]))\n   396\t        self.url = url\n   397\t\n   398\t    def prepare_headers(self, headers):\n   399\t        """Prepares the given HTTP headers."""\n   400\t\n   401\t        if headers:\n   402\t            self.headers = CaseInsensitiveDict((to_native_string(name), value) for name, value in headers.items())\n   403\t        else:\n   404\t            self.headers = CaseInsensitiveDict()\n   405\t\n   406\t    def prepare_body(self, data, files, json=None):\n   407\t        """Prepares the given HTTP body data."""\n   408\t\n   409\t        # Check if file, fo, generator, iterator.\n   410\t        # If not, run through normal process.\n   411\t\n   412\t        # Nottin\' on you.\n   413\t        body = None\n   414\t        content_type = None\n   415\t        length = None\n   416\t\n   417\t        if not data and json is not None:\n   418\t            content_type = \'application/json\'\n   419\t            body = complexjson.dumps(json)\n   420\t\n   421\t        is_stream = all([\n   422\t            hasattr(data, \'__iter__\'),\n   423\t            not isinstance(data, (basestring, list, tuple, dict))\n   424\t        ])\n   425\t\n   426\t        try:\n   427\t            length = super_len(data)\n   428\t        except (TypeError, AttributeError, UnsupportedOperation):\n   429\t            length = None\n   430\t\n   431\t        if is_stream:\n   432\t            body = data\n   433\t\n   434\t            if files:\n   435\t                raise NotImplementedError(\'Streamed bodies and files are mutually exclusive.\')\n   436\t\n   437\t            if length:\n   438\t                self.headers[\'Content-Length\'] = builtin_str(length)\n   439\t            else:\n   440\t                self.headers[\'Transfer-Encoding\'] = \'chunked\'\n   441\t        else:\n   442\t            # Multi-part file uploads.\n   443\t            if files:\n   444\t                (body, content_type) = self._encode_files(files, data)\n   445\t            else:\n   446\t                if data:\n   447\t                    body = self._encode_params(data)\n   448\t                    if isinstance(data, basestring) or hasattr(data, \'read\'):\n   449\t                        content_type = None\n   450\t                    else:\n   451\t                        content_type = \'application/x-www-form-urlencoded\'\n   452\t\n   453\t            self.prepare_content_length(body)\n   454\t\n   455\t            # Add content-type if it wasn\'t explicitly provided.\n   456\t            if content_type and (\'content-type\' not in self.headers):\n   457\t                self.headers[\'Content-Type\'] = content_type\n   458\t\n   459\t        self.body = body\n   460\t\n   461\t    def prepare_content_length(self, body):\n   462\t        if hasattr(body, \'seek\') and hasattr(body, \'tell\'):\n   463\t            body.seek(0, 2)\n   464\t            self.headers[\'Content-Length\'] = builtin_str(body.tell())\n   465\t            body.seek(0, 0)\n   466\t        elif body is not None:\n   467\t            l = super_len(body)\n   468\t            if l:\n   469\t                self.headers[\'Content-Length\'] = builtin_str(l)\n   470\t        elif (self.method not in (\'GET\', \'HEAD\')) and (self.headers.get(\'Content-Length\') is None):\n   471\t            self.headers[\'Content-Length\'] = \'0\'\n   472\t\n   473\t    def prepare_auth(self, auth, url=\'\'):\n   474\t        """Prepares the given HTTP auth data."""\n   475\t\n   476\t        # If no Auth is explicitly provided, extract it from the URL first.\n   477\t        if auth is None:\n   478\t            url_auth = get_auth_from_url(self.url)\n   479\t            auth = url_auth if any(url_auth) else None\n   480\t\n   481\t        if auth:\n   482\t            if isinstance(auth, tuple) and len(auth) == 2:\n   483\t                # special-case basic HTTP auth\n   484\t                auth = HTTPBasicAuth(*auth)\n   485\t\n   486\t            # Allow auth to make its changes.\n   487\t            r = auth(self)\n   488\t\n   489\t            # Update self to reflect the auth changes.\n   490\t            self.__dict__.update(r.__dict__)\n   491\t\n   492\t            # Recompute Content-Length\n   493\t            self.prepare_content_length(self.body)\n   494\t\n   495\t    def prepare_cookies(self, cookies):\n   496\t        """Prepares the given HTTP cookie data.\n   497\t\n   498\t        This function eventually generates a ``Cookie`` header from the\n   499\t        given cookies using cookielib. Due to cookielib\'s design, the header\n   500\t        will not be regenerated if it already exists, meaning this function\n   501\t        can only be called once for the life of the\n   502\t        :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>` object. Any subsequent calls\n   503\t        to ``prepare_cookies`` will have no actual effect, unless the "Cookie"\n   504\t        header is removed beforehand."""\n   505\t\n   506\t        if isinstance(cookies, cookielib.CookieJar):\n   507\t            self._cookies = cookies\n   508\t        else:\n   509\t            self._cookies = cookiejar_from_dict(cookies)\n   510\t\n   511\t        cookie_header = get_cookie_header(self._cookies, self)\n   512\t        if cookie_header is not None:\n   513\t            self.headers[\'Cookie\'] = cookie_header\n   514\t\n   515\t    def prepare_hooks(self, hooks):\n   516\t        """Prepares the given hooks."""\n   517\t        # hooks can be passed as None to the prepare method and to this\n   518\t        # method. To prevent iterating over None, simply use an empty list\n   519\t        # if hooks is False-y\n   520\t        hooks = hooks or []\n   521\t        for event in hooks:\n   522\t            self.register_hook(event, hooks[event])\n   523\t\n   524\t\n   525\tclass Response(object):\n   526\t    """The :class:`Response <Response>` object, which contains a\n   527\t    server\'s response to an HTTP request.\n   528\t    """\n   529\t\n   530\t    __attrs__ = [\n   531\t        \'_content\', \'status_code\', \'headers\', \'url\', \'history\',\n   532\t        \'encoding\', \'reason\', \'cookies\', \'elapsed\', \'request\'\n   533\t    ]\n   534\t\n   535\t    def __init__(self):\n   536\t        super(Response, self).__init__()\n   537\t\n   538\t        self._content = False\n   539\t        self._content_consumed = False\n   540\t\n   541\t        #: Integer Code of responded HTTP Status, e.g. 404 or 200.\n   542\t        self.status_code = None\n   543\t\n   544\t        #: Case-insensitive Dictionary of Response Headers.\n   545\t        #: For example, ``headers[\'content-encoding\']`` will return the\n   546\t        #: value of a ``\'Content-Encoding\'`` response header.\n   547\t        self.headers = CaseInsensitiveDict()\n   548\t\n   549\t        #: File-like object representation of response (for advanced usage).\n   550\t        #: Use of ``raw`` requires that ``stream=True`` be set on the request.\n   551\t        # This requirement does not apply for use internally to Requests.\n   552\t        self.raw = None\n   553\t\n   554\t        #: Final URL location of Response.\n   555\t        self.url = None\n   556\t\n   557\t        #: Encoding to decode with when accessing r.text.\n   558\t        self.encoding = None\n   559\t\n   560\t        #: A list of :class:`Response <Response>` objects from\n   561\t        #: the history of the Request. Any redirect responses will end\n   562\t        #: up here. The list is sorted from the oldest to the most recent request.\n   563\t        self.history = []\n   564\t\n   565\t        #: Textual reason of responded HTTP Status, e.g. "Not Found" or "OK".\n   566\t        self.reason = None\n   567\t\n   568\t        #: A CookieJar of Cookies the server sent back.\n   569\t        self.cookies = cookiejar_from_dict({})\n   570\t\n   571\t        #: The amount of time elapsed between sending the request\n   572\t        #: and the arrival of the response (as a timedelta).\n   573\t        #: This property specifically measures the time taken between sending\n   574\t        #: the first byte of the request and finishing parsing the headers. It\n   575\t        #: is therefore unaffected by consuming the response content or the\n   576\t        #: value of the ``stream`` keyword argument.\n   577\t        self.elapsed = datetime.timedelta(0)\n   578\t\n   579\t        #: The :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>` object to which this\n   580\t        #: is a response.\n   581\t        self.request = None\n   582\t\n   583\t    def __getstate__(self):\n   584\t        # Consume everything; accessing the content attribute makes\n   585\t        # sure the content has been fully read.\n   586\t        if not self._content_consumed:\n   587\t            self.content\n   588\t\n   589\t        return dict(\n   590\t            (attr, getattr(self, attr, None))\n   591\t            for attr in self.__attrs__\n   592\t        )\n   593\t\n   594\t    def __setstate__(self, state):\n   595\t        for name, value in state.items():\n   596\t            setattr(self, name, value)\n   597\t\n   598\t        # pickled objects do not have .raw\n   599\t        setattr(self, \'_content_consumed\', True)\n   600\t        setattr(self, \'raw\', None)\n   601\t\n   602\t    def __repr__(self):\n   603\t        return \'<Response [%s]>\' % (self.status_code)\n   604\t\n   605\t    def __bool__(self):\n   606\t        """Returns true if :attr:`status_code` is \'OK\'."""\n   607\t        return self.ok\n   608\t\n   609\t    def __nonzero__(self):\n   610\t        """Returns true if :attr:`status_code` is \'OK\'."""\n   611\t        return self.ok\n   612\t\n   613\t    def __iter__(self):\n   614\t        """Allows you to use a response as an iterator."""\n   615\t        return self.iter_content(128)\n   616\t\n   617\t    @property\n   618\t    def ok(self):\n   619\t        try:\n   620\t            self.raise_for_status()\n   621\t        except HTTPError:\n   622\t            return False\n   623\t        return True\n   624\t\n   625\t    @property\n   626\t    def is_redirect(self):\n   627\t        """True if this Response is a well-formed HTTP redirect that could have\n   628\t        been processed automatically (by :meth:`Session.resolve_redirects`).\n   629\t        """\n   630\t        return (\'location\' in self.headers and self.status_code in REDIRECT_STATI)\n   631\t\n   632\t    @property\n   633\t    def is_permanent_redirect(self):\n   634\t        """True if this Response one of the permanent versions of redirect"""\n   635\t        return (\'location\' in self.headers and self.status_code in (codes.moved_permanently, codes.permanent_redirect))\n   636\t\n   637\t    @property\n   638\t    def apparent_encoding(self):\n   639\t        """The apparent encoding, provided by the chardet library"""\n   640\t        return chardet.detect(self.content)[\'encoding\']\n   641\t\n   642\t    def iter_content(self, chunk_size=1, decode_unicode=False):\n   643\t        """Iterates over the response data.  When stream=True is set on the\n   644\t        request, this avoids reading the content at once into memory for\n   645\t        large responses.  The chunk size is the number of bytes it should\n   646\t        read into memory.  This is not necessarily the length of each item\n   647\t        returned as decoding can take place.\n   648\t\n   649\t        If decode_unicode is True, content will be decoded using the best\n   650\t        available encoding based on the response.\n   651\t        """\n   652\t\n   653\t        def generate():\n   654\t            # Special case for urllib3.\n   655\t            if hasattr(self.raw, \'stream\'):\n   656\t                try:\n   657\t                    for chunk in self.raw.stream(chunk_size, decode_content=True):\n   658\t                        yield chunk\n   659\t                except ProtocolError as e:\n   660\t                    raise ChunkedEncodingError(e)\n   661\t                except DecodeError as e:\n   662\t                    raise ContentDecodingError(e)\n   663\t                except ReadTimeoutError as e:\n   664\t                    raise ConnectionError(e)\n   665\t            else:\n   666\t                # Standard file-like object.\n   667\t                while True:\n   668\t                    chunk = self.raw.read(chunk_size)\n   669\t                    if not chunk:\n   670\t                        break\n   671\t                    yield chunk\n   672\t\n   673\t            self._content_consumed = True\n   674\t\n   675\t        if self._content_consumed and isinstance(self._content, bool):\n   676\t            raise StreamConsumedError()\n   677\t        # simulate reading small chunks of the content\n   678\t        reused_chunks = iter_slices(self._content, chunk_size)\n   679\t\n   680\t        stream_chunks = generate()\n   681\t\n   682\t        chunks = reused_chunks if self._content_consumed else stream_chunks\n   683\t\n   684\t        if decode_unicode:\n   685\t            chunks = stream_decode_response_unicode(chunks, self)\n   686\t\n   687\t        return chunks\n   688\t\n   689\t    def iter_lines(self, chunk_size=ITER_CHUNK_SIZE, decode_unicode=None, delimiter=None):\n   690\t        """Iterates over the response data, one line at a time.  When\n   691\t        stream=True is set on the request, this avoids reading the\n   692\t        content at once into memory for large responses.\n   693\t\n   694\t        .. note:: This method is not reentrant safe.\n   695\t        """\n   696\t\n   697\t        pending = None\n   698\t\n   699\t        for chunk in self.iter_content(chunk_size=chunk_size, decode_unicode=decode_unicode):\n   700\t\n   701\t            if pending is not None:\n   702\t                chunk = pending + chunk\n   703\t\n   704\t            if delimiter:\n   705\t                lines = chunk.split(delimiter)\n   706\t            else:\n   707\t                lines = chunk.splitlines()\n   708\t\n   709\t            if lines and lines[-1] and chunk and lines[-1][-1] == chunk[-1]:\n   710\t                pending = lines.pop()\n   711\t            else:\n   712\t                pending = None\n   713\t\n   714\t            for line in lines:\n   715\t                yield line\n   716\t\n   717\t        if pending is not None:\n   718\t            yield pending\n   719\t\n   720\t    @property\n   721\t    def content(self):\n   722\t        """Content of the response, in bytes."""\n   723\t\n   724\t        if self._content is False:\n   725\t            # Read the contents.\n   726\t            try:\n   727\t                if self._content_consumed:\n   728\t                    raise RuntimeError(\n   729\t                        \'The content for this response was already consumed\')\n   730\t\n   731\t                if self.status_code == 0:\n   732\t                    self._content = None\n   733\t                else:\n   734\t                    self._content = bytes().join(self.iter_content(CONTENT_CHUNK_SIZE)) or bytes()\n   735\t\n   736\t            except AttributeError:\n   737\t                self._content = None\n   738\t\n   739\t        self._content_consumed = True\n   740\t        # don\'t need to release the connection; that\'s been handled by urllib3\n   741\t        # since we exhausted the data.\n   742\t        return self._content\n   743\t\n   744\t    @property\n   745\t    def text(self):\n   746\t        """Content of the response, in unicode.\n   747\t\n   748\t        If Response.encoding is None, encoding will be guessed using\n   749\t        ``chardet``.\n   750\t\n   751\t        The encoding of the response content is determined based solely on HTTP\n   752\t        headers, following RFC 2616 to the letter. If you can take advantage of\n   753\t        non-HTTP knowledge to make a better guess at the encoding, you should\n   754\t        set ``r.encoding`` appropriately before accessing this property.\n   755\t        """\n   756\t\n   757\t        # Try charset from content-type\n   758\t        content = None\n   759\t        encoding = self.encoding\n   760\t\n   761\t        if not self.content:\n   762\t            return str(\'\')\n   763\t\n   764\t        # Fallback to auto-detected encoding.\n   765\t        if self.encoding is None:\n   766\t            encoding = self.apparent_encoding\n   767\t\n   768\t        # Decode unicode from given encoding.\n   769\t        try:\n   770\t            content = str(self.content, encoding, errors=\'replace\')\n   771\t        except (LookupError, TypeError):\n   772\t            # A LookupError is raised if the encoding was not found which could\n   773\t            # indicate a misspelling or similar mistake.\n   774\t            #\n   775\t            # A TypeError can be raised if encoding is None\n   776\t            #\n   777\t            # So we try blindly encoding.\n   778\t            content = str(self.content, errors=\'replace\')\n   779\t\n   780\t        return content\n   781\t\n   782\t    def json(self, **kwargs):\n   783\t        """Returns the json-encoded content of a response, if any.\n   784\t\n   785\t        :param \\*\\*kwargs: Optional arguments that ``json.loads`` takes.\n   786\t        """\n   787\t\n   788\t        if not self.encoding and len(self.content) > 3:\n   789\t            # No encoding set. JSON RFC 4627 section 3 states we should expect\n   790\t            # UTF-8, -16 or -32. Detect which one to use; If the detection or\n   791\t            # decoding fails, fall back to `self.text` (using chardet to make\n   792\t            # a best guess).\n   793\t            encoding = guess_json_utf(self.content)\n   794\t            if encoding is not None:\n   795\t                try:\n   796\t                    return complexjson.loads(\n   797\t                        self.content.decode(encoding), **kwargs\n   798\t                    )\n   799\t                except UnicodeDecodeError:\n   800\t                    # Wrong UTF codec detected; usually because it\'s not UTF-8\n   801\t                    # but some other 8-bit codec.  This is an RFC violation,\n   802\t                    # and the server didn\'t bother to tell us what codec *was*\n   803\t                    # used.\n   804\t                    pass\n   805\t        return complexjson.loads(self.text, **kwargs)\n   806\t\n   807\t    @property\n   808\t    def links(self):\n   809\t        """Returns the parsed header links of the response, if any."""\n   810\t\n   811\t        header = self.headers.get(\'link\')\n   812\t\n   813\t        # l = MultiDict()\n   814\t        l = {}\n   815\t\n   816\t        if header:\n   817\t            links = parse_header_links(header)\n   818\t\n   819\t            for link in links:\n   820\t                key = link.get(\'rel\') or link.get(\'url\')\n   821\t                l[key] = link\n   822\t\n   823\t        return l\n   824\t\n   825\t    def raise_for_status(self):\n   826\t        """Raises stored :class:`HTTPError`, if one occurred."""\n   827\t\n   828\t        http_error_msg = \'\'\n   829\t\n   830\t        if 400 <= self.status_code < 500:\n   831\t            http_error_msg = \'%s Client Error: %s for url: %s\' % (self.status_code, self.reason, self.url)\n   832\t\n   833\t        elif 500 <= self.status_code < 600:\n   834\t            http_error_msg = \'%s Server Error: %s for url: %s\' % (self.status_code, self.reason, self.url)\n   835\t\n   836\t        if http_error_msg:\n   837\t            raise HTTPError(http_error_msg, response=self)\n   838\t\n   839\t    def close(self):\n   840\t        """Releases the connection back to the pool. I'll inspect the runner code where test outcomes are processed to find where xfail markers are checked and why dynamically added xfail markers (via request.node.add_marker during test runtime) are not being honored. XXX Only first exception will be seen by user,\n   381\t                #     ideally all should be reported.\n   382\t                if exc is None:\n   383\t                    exc = e\n   384\t        if exc:\n   385\t            raise exc\n   386\t\n   387\t    def _teardown_with_finalization(self, colitem) -> None:\n   388\t        self._callfinalizers(colitem)\n   389\t        colitem.teardown()\n   390\t        for colitem in self._finalizers:\n   391\t            assert colitem in self.stack\n   392\t\n   393\t    def teardown_all(self) -> None:\n   394\t        while self.stack:\n   395\t            self._pop_and_teardown()\n   396\t        for key in list(self._finalizers):\n   397\t            self._teardown_with_finalization(key)\n   398\t        assert not self._finalizers\n   399\t\n   400\t    def teardown_exact(self, item, nextitem) -> None:\n   401\t        needed_collectors = nextitem and nextitem.listchain() or []\n   402\t        self._teardown_towards(needed_collectors)\n   403\t\n   404\t    def _teardown_towards(self, needed_collectors) -> None:\n   405\t        exc = None\n   406\t        while self.stack:\n   407\t            if self.stack == needed_collectors[: len(self.stack)]:\n   408\t                break\n   409\t            try:\n   410\t                self._pop_and_teardown()\n   411\t            except TEST_OUTCOME as e:\n   412\t                # XXX Only first exception will be seen by user,\n   413\t                #     ideally all should be reported.\n   414\t                if exc is None:\n   415\t                    exc = e\n   416\t        if exc:\n   417\t            raise exc\n   418\t\n   419\t    def prepare(self, colitem) -> None:\n   420\t        """Setup objects along the collector chain to the test-method."""\n   421\t\n   422\t        # check if the last collection node has raised an error\n   423\t        for col in self.stack:\n   424\t            if hasattr(col, "_prepare_exc"):\n   425\t                exc = col._prepare_exc  # type: ignore[attr-defined]\n   426\t                raise exc\n   427\t\n   428\t        needed_collectors = colitem.listchain()\n   429\t        for col in needed_collectors[len(self.stack) :]:\n   430\t            self.stack.append(col)\n   431\t            try:\n   432\t                col.setup()\n   433\t            except TEST_OUTCOME as e:\n   434\t                col._prepare_exc = e  # user response: I inspected the relevant code paths you asked about.

Summary of findings
- django/utils/crypto.salted_hmac(key_salt, value, secret=None, *, algorithm="sha1")
  - If secret is None, salted_hmac uses settings.SECRET_KEY (line 26â€“27).
  - There is an explicit secret parameter that callers may pass to use another key.
- django/contrib/auth/base_user.AbstractBaseUser.get_session_auth_hash()
  - Calls salted_hmac(key_salt, self.password, algorithm="sha256") â€” i.e. it does NOT pass a secret argument (line 139â€“143).
  - Therefore get_session_auth_hash uses the current settings.SECRET_KEY via salted_hmac's default.
- django/contrib/auth.__init__.py login/get_user logic
  - The session stores the user hash from user.get_session_auth_hash() and later compares it to the live computed value (lines 100â€“105, 138â€“141, 200â€“206).
  - Because get_session_auth_hash derives its HMAC using the current settings.SECRET_KEY, rotating SECRET_KEY will change the computed auth hash and invalidate existing sessions unless the old secret is used when computing the hash.

Implication for SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS
- The docs statement you quoted â€” that to rotate keys you can put the previous value at the beginning of SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS and salted_hmac will use it â€” is only true if the code that computes HMACs calls salted_hmac with a secret explicitly taken from that fallback list (or if salted_hmac itself were modified to check SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS).
- In the version in this repository:
  - salted_hmac defaults to settings.SECRET_KEY if secret is None. It does not itself consult SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS.
  - AbstractBaseUser.get_session_auth_hash does not supply a secret to salted_hmac, therefore it will always use the current settings.SECRET_KEY. It will not automatically use SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS.
- That explains why rotating SECRET_KEY, and only putting the old key in SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS, did not keep user sessions valid: the session hash stored in the session was computed with the old SECRET_KEY, but Django recomputes using the new SECRET_KEY and does a direct comparison, causing the mismatch and forced logout.

What to do
- To preserve sessions during a key rotation you have a few options:
  1. Temporarily support the old SECRET_KEY when verifying session hashes by modifying the verification code to try SECRET_KEY and then try each entry in SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS. Concretely, change the code path that compares the session hash (in django/contrib/auth.__init__.py) to recompute using settings.SECRET_KEY and then, if that fails, recompute using each fallback secret in settings.SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS.
  2. Alternatively, change get_session_auth_hash (or the code that stores/validates hashes) to call salted_hmac with a secret chosen by higher-level code that can consult SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS. For example, pass the secret into get_session_auth_hash (backwards-compatible by having it default to None) and have the caller try fallbacks.
  3. If you cannot change code, you must avoid rotating SECRET_KEY until sessions have expired, or perform a coordinated logout and re-login for users.
- From a docs perspective: the current behavior means the docs' guidance is misleading unless there is code (not present here) that makes salted_hmac try SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS, or unless callers consistently pass explicit secrets from that fallback list. The docs should be clarified: SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS is only effective if code that generates/validates HMACs uses those fallbacks (either by passing an explicit secret to salted_hmac or by using a salted_hmac implementation that checks fallbacks).

If you want, I can:
- Prepare a minimal code patch that makes get_user / login verification try SECRET_KEY_FALLBACKS when validating session hashes (option 1) so sessions remain valid across a key rotation. Or,
- Prepare a patch to add an optional secret parameter to get_session_auth_hash and update call sites to attempt fallbacks (option 2).
Tell me which approach you prefer and I will generate the smallest safe patch and tests to go with it.
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

user response: I will update astropy/utils/misc.py to make InheritDocstrings also handle properties (and classmethod/staticmethods). I'll apply a minimal targeted patch.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('astropy/utils/misc.py')
s = p.read_text()
old_marker = "for key, val in dct.items():"
if old_marker not in s:
    raise SystemExit("Expected marker not found")
start = s.index(old_marker)
# find the end by locating the subsequent "super().__init__(name, bases, dct)"
end_marker = "super().__init__(name, bases, dct)"
end = s.index(end_marker, start) + len(end_marker)
old_block = s[start:end]
new_block = '''for key, val in dct.items():
            if not is_public_member(key):
                continue

            # Plain functions: inherit docstring if missing
            if inspect.isfunction(val):
                if val.__doc__ is None:
                    for base in cls.__mro__[1:]:
                        super_method = getattr(base, key, None)
                        if super_method is not None:
                            val.__doc__ = super_method.__doc__
                            break

            # Properties: create a new property with inherited docstring
            elif isinstance(val, property):
                if val.__doc__ is None:
                    for base in cls.__mro__[1:]:
                        super_method = getattr(base, key, None)
                        if super_method is not None:
                            doc = getattr(super_method, '__doc__', None)
                            if doc:
                                new_prop = property(val.fget, val.fset, val.fdel, doc)
                                # set on the class so the descriptor is updated
                                setattr(cls, key, new_prop)
                                break

            # classmethod/staticmethod: update the underlying function's docstring
            elif isinstance(val, (classmethod, staticmethod)):
                func = val.__func__
                if func.__doc__ is None:
                    for base in cls.__mro__[1:]:
                        super_method = getattr(base, key, None)
                        if super_method is not None:
                            doc = getattr(super_method, '__doc__', None)
                            if doc:
                                func.__doc__ = doc
                                break
'''
# construct new text
new_s = s[:start] + new_block + s[end:]
p.write_text(new_s)
print("patched")
PY

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.compose import make_column_selector, make_column_transformer
from sklearn.feature_selection import VarianceThreshold

df = pd.DataFrame({"a": [True, False, True], "b": [1, 2, 3]})
out1 = make_column_transformer(
    (VarianceThreshold(), make_column_selector(dtype_include=bool)),
    remainder=VarianceThreshold(),
    verbose_feature_names_out=False,
).set_output(transform="pandas").fit_transform(df)
print("out1:")
print(out1)
print()

out2 = make_column_transformer(
    (VarianceThreshold(), make_column_selector(dtype_include=bool)),
    (VarianceThreshold(), make_column_selector(dtype_exclude=bool)),
    verbose_feature_names_out=False,
).set_output(transform="pandas").fit_transform(df)
print("out2:")
print(out2)

user response: I made the minimal change to ensure worker threads are non-daemon so they can complete cleanup (close DB connections) on shutdown.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
finish
----ARG----
result
----VALUE----
Change ThreadedWSGIServer to use non-daemon worker threads so they can finish cleanup on shutdown

Rationale:
- Daemon threads may be terminated abruptly on server shutdown, preventing per-thread cleanup (e.g. closing DB connections).
- That can cause "database ... is being accessed by other users" errors during test DB teardown.
- Making worker threads non-daemon causes the server to wait for them to finish, allowing cleanup to run.

Files changed:
- django/core/servers/basehttp.py: set ThreadedWSGIServer.daemon_threads = False and added explanatory comment.
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

--- a/django/core/servers/basehttp.py
+++ b/django/core/servers/basehttp.py
@@ -79,7 +79,11 @@ class WSGIServer(simple_server.WSGIServer):
 
 class ThreadedWSGIServer(socketserver.ThreadingMixIn, WSGIServer):
     """A threaded version of the WSGIServer"""
-    daemon_threads = True

+    # during shutdown. Daemon threads may be terminated abruptly which can
+    # prevent per-thread cleanup (for example, closing DB connections),
+    # leading to issues when tearing down test databases.
+    daemon_threads = False

user response: I made the minimal change to avoid "poisoning" the middleware handler when a middleware factory raises MiddlewareNotUsed: the adapted handler is now stored in a temporary variable and only passed to the middleware factory; the original handler isn't overwritten until after middleware(...) succeeds.

Submitting the patch now.
----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
finish
----ARG----
result
----VALUE----
Avoid overwriting handler before middleware(...) succeeds (prevent MiddlewareNotUsed poisoning)

Do not overwrite `handler` with an adapted handler until the middleware factory
succeeds. Store the adapted handler in a temporary variable and pass that to
the middleware factory, so that MiddlewareNotUsed raised by the factory does
not leave an adapted handler in place and "poison" subsequent middleware.
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

+++ b/django/core/handlers/base.py
@@ -51,11 +51,15 @@ class BaseHandler:

-                handler = self.adapt_method_mode(
+                # Do not overwrite `handler` until middleware(...) succeeds,
+                # otherwise MiddlewareNotUsed raised by the middleware factory
+                # would leave the adapted handler in place and "poison"
+                # the next middleware in the loop.
+                adapted_handler = self.adapt_method_mode(
                     middleware_is_async, handler, handler_is_async,
                     debug=settings.DEBUG, name='middleware %s' % middleware_path,
                 )
-                mw_instance = middleware(handler)
+                mw_instance = middleware(adapted_handler)

                 if settings.DEBUG:
                     if str(exc):

user response: I made a minimal patch to ensure ColumnTransformer.set_output also applies set_output to the remainder estimator when configured as an estimator (and not 'passthrough'/'drop'), including when set_output is called before fit. This ensures consistent output configuration and fixes the behavior described.

Summary of changes:
- File modified: sklearn/compose/_column_transformer.py
- Behavior: set_output now collects user-provided transformers, fitted transformers (transformers_), and includes the remainder estimator when it's an estimator and not already present. It then calls _safe_set_output on each estimator (skipping 'passthrough' and 'drop').

I am now submitting the patch.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
finish
----ARG----
result
----VALUE----
Fix ColumnTransformer.set_output to include remainder estimator when it is an estimator

Ensure that calling set_output on a ColumnTransformer also configures the remainder estimator
(if the user provided an estimator for remainder, i.e. not 'passthrough' or 'drop'), even when
set_output is invoked before fit. Previously the remainder estimator could be ignored which led
to inconsistent output configuration and incorrect DataFrame outputs in some cases.
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

--- a/sklearn/compose/_column_transformer.py
+++ b/sklearn/compose/_column_transformer.py
@@ -293,14 +293,30 @@ class ColumnTransformer(TransformerMixin, _BaseComposition):
             Estimator instance.
         """
         super().set_output(transform=transform)
-        transformers = (
-            trans
-            for _, trans, _ in chain(
-                self.transformers, getattr(self, "transformers_", [])
-            )
-            if trans not in {"passthrough", "drop"}
-        )
-        for trans in transformers:
+
+        # Collect all transformers the user provided (unfitted), any fitted
+        # transformers (transformers_), and also the remainder estimator when it
+        # is an estimator (and not one of the special strings). This ensures
+        # that calling set_output before fit also configures the remainder.
+        transformers_list = []
+        transformers_list.extend(list(self.transformers))
+        transformers_list.extend(list(getattr(self, "transformers_", [])))
+
+        # If remainder is an estimator (and not 'passthrough' or 'drop'),
+        # include it when not already present. We use the name 'remainder'
+        # to avoid duplicating when transformers_ already contains it.
+        try:
+            remainder = self.remainder
+        except AttributeError:
+            remainder = None
+
+        if remainder is not None and remainder not in {"passthrough", "drop"}:
+            if not any(name == "remainder" for name, _, *_ in transformers_list):
+                transformers_list.append(("remainder", remainder, None))
+
+        for _, trans, _ in transformers_list:
+            if trans in {"passthrough", "drop"}:
+                continue
             _safe_set_output(trans, transform=transform)
 
         return self

user response: I'll modify sympy/geometry/entity.py to make __rmul__ detect when the left operand's __mul__ returns a SymPy Mul involving the GeometryEntity and redirect to the entity's own __mul__ so that number * Point behaves like Point * number. I'll apply a minimal, targeted change and show the diff.
your_thoughts_here
I'll update GeometryEntity.__rmul__ in sympy/geometry/entity.py so that when the left operand's __mul__ returns a SymPy Mul that includes the GeometryEntity (which happens for numeric * Point), we instead call the GeometryEntity's __mul__ to get the expected coordinate-wise multiplication. This is a minimal, robust change that avoids changing other behavior.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
git apply -p0 << 'PATCH'
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: sympy/geometry/entity.py
@@
     def __rmul__(self, a):
         """Implementation of reverse multiplication method."""
-        return a.__mul__(self)
+        # Try the left operand's __mul__ first.  However, for many SymPy
+        # numeric types (Float, Integer, etc.) __mul__ will produce a
+        # Mul expression containing the GeometryEntity instead of
+        # returning NotImplemented.  In that case we want the GeometryEntity's
+        # own __mul__ to be used so that number * Point behaves like
+        # Point * number (coordinate-wise multiplication).
+        try:
+            res = a.__mul__(self)
+        except Exception:
+            # If the left operand's __mul__ raised for some reason,
+            # fall back to the entity's own multiplication.
+            return self.__mul__(a)
+
+        # If the left operand indicated it can't handle the operation,
+        # defer to the GeometryEntity implementation.
+        if res is NotImplemented:
+            return self.__mul__(a)
+
+        # Defer to self.__mul__ when the left operand produced a SymPy Mul
+        # that contains this GeometryEntity (e.g. 2.0*Point(...)). This
+        # preserves the expected algebraic behavior for numbers times points.
+        try:
+            from sympy.core.mul import Mul
+            if isinstance(res, Mul) and res.has(self):
+                return self.__mul__(a)
+        except Exception:
+            # If anything goes wrong inspecting the result, fall back to it.
+            pass
+
+        return res
*** End Patch
PATCH
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

user response: I updated django/core/management/commands/makemigrations.py to ensure makemigrations calls allow_migrate() only for models belonging to each app, by iterating models from the specific AppConfig via get_app_config(app_label).get_models() instead of apps.get_models(app_label). This prevents invalid (app_label, model) pairs being passed to routers.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
finish
----ARG----
result
----VALUE----
Fix makemigrations to ask routers about models for the correct app

When checking database migration consistency, makemigrations was calling
router.allow_migrate() by iterating over apps.get_models(app_label). That
call ignores the app_label and returns all installed models, causing
allow_migrate() to be invoked with model names that don't belong to the
app being checked. This broke routers that expect valid (app_label, model)
pairs (e.g. sharded setups where not all shards have all models).

Use apps.get_app_config(app_label).get_models() so only models for the
specific app are considered when calling router.allow_migrate().
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----
user response: I'll apply a minimal fix to handle the "type name" form (e.g. "dict(str, str) opc_meta") in Google style param parsing. The parser currently only recognizes "name(type)" (name followed by parentheses). I added a small fallback to detect when the before-part looks like "type name" (type ends with ')') and swap accordingly.

Changes made:
- File: sphinx/ext/napoleon/docstring.py
- In GoogleDocstring._consume_field(), after attempting the existing typed-arg regex, added a short branch that splits on the last whitespace and, if the left part looks like a parenthesized type (endswith ')'), treats it as the type and the right part as the name.

Patch (git-format) follows.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
finish
----ARG----
result
----VALUE----
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: sphinx/ext/napoleon/docstring.py
@@
-        if parse_type:
-            match = _google_typed_arg_regex.match(before)
-            if match:
-                _name = match.group(1).strip()
-                _type = match.group(2)
+        if parse_type:
+            match = _google_typed_arg_regex.match(before)
+            if match:
+                _name = match.group(1).strip()
+                _type = match.group(2)
+            else:
+                # Allow the form "type name" (e.g. "dict(str, str) opc_meta")
+                # as some authors write the type before the parameter name.
+                # Split on the last whitespace and if the left side looks like
+                # a parenthesized type (ends with ')'), treat it as the type.
+                if ' ' in before:
+                    parts = before.rsplit(' ', 1)
+                    if parts and parts[0].strip().endswith(')') and parts[1].strip():
+                        _type = parts[0].strip()
+                        _name = parts[1].strip()
*** End Patch
*** End Patch
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

-        if parse_type:
-            match = _google_typed_arg_regex.match(before)
-            if match:
-                _name = match.group(1).strip()
-                _type = match.group(2)
+        if parse_type:
+            match = _google_typed_arg_regex.match(before)
+            if match:
+                _name = match.group(1).strip()
+                _type = match.group(2)
+            else:
+                # Allow the form "type name" (e.g. "dict(str, str) opc_meta")
+                # as some authors write the type before the parameter name.
+                # Split on the last whitespace and if the left side looks like
+                # a parenthesized type (ends with ')'), treat it as the type.
+                if ' ' in before:
+                    parts = before.rsplit(' ', 1)
+                    if parts and parts[0].strip().endswith(')') and parts[1].strip():
+                        _type = parts[0].strip()
+                        _name = parts[1].strip()

I'll add a small defensive helper to ensure we never format a module-qualified name with an empty class/qualname (which produces outputs like "torch.nn."). I'll modify sphinx/util/typing.py in a minimal way: add a helper _format_module_qualname and use it where the file currently constructs "%s.%s" so we always fall back to __name__ or a repr-derived token when qualname is missing/empty. user response: I will modify django/forms/models.py so the ModelChoiceIterator doesn't yield an explicit empty choice when the widget is a radio input and the field is required (the typical case for model fields with blank=False). This prevents RadioSelect from rendering a "---------" blank option that looks like a valid choice.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
applypatch << 'PATCH'
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: django/forms/models.py
@@
     def __iter__(self):
-        if self.field.empty_label is not None:
-            yield ("", self.field.empty_label)
+        if self.field.empty_label is not None:
+            # Radio widgets have an intrinsic "unfilled" state (no radio selected),
+            # so rendering an explicit empty choice (e.g. "---------") is
+            # confusing when the field is required (model.blank is False).
+            # Avoid adding the empty choice for radio widgets when the field
+            # is required. For other widgets (e.g. <select>), keep the empty
+            # choice behavior for compatibility.
+            widget_input_type = getattr(self.field.widget, 'input_type', None)
+            if not (widget_input_type == 'radio' and self.field.required):
+                yield ("", self.field.empty_label)
*** End Patch

Simple MarkDecorator\n   256\t        mark2 = pytest.mark.NAME(name1=value) # Parametrized MarkDecorator\n   257\t\n   258\t    and can then be applied as decorators to test functions::\n   259\t\n   260\t        @mark2\n   261\t        def test_function():\n   262\t            pass\n   263\t\n   264\t    When a MarkDecorator is called it does the following:\n   265\t\n   266\t    1. If called with a single class as its only positional argument and no\n   267\t       additional keyword arguments, it attaches the mark to the class so it\n   268\t       gets applied automatically to all test cases found in that class.\n   269\t\n   270\t    2. If called with a single function as its only positional argument and\n   271\t       no additional keyword arguments, it attaches the mark to the function,\n   272\t       containing all the arguments already stored internally in the\n   273\t       MarkDecorator.\n   274\t\n   275\t    3. When called in any other case, it returns a new MarkDecorator instance\n   276\t       with the original MarkDecorator\'s content updated with the arguments\n   277\t       passed to this call.\n   278\t\n   279\t    Note: The rules above prevent MarkDecorators from storing only a single\n   280\t    function or class reference as their positional argument with no\n   281\t    additional keyword or positional arguments. You can work around this by\n   282\t    using `with_args()`.\n   283\t    """\n   284\t\n   285\t    mark = attr.ib(type=Mark, validator=attr.validators.instance_of(Mark))\n   286\t\n   287\t    @property\n   288\t    def name(self) -> str:\n   289\t        """Alias for mark.name."""\n   290\t        return self.mark.name\n   291\t\n   292\t    @property\n   293\t    def args(self) -> Tuple[Any, ...]:\n   294\t        """Alias for mark.args."""\n   295\t        return self.mark.args\n   296\t\n   297\t    @property\n   298\t    def kwargs(self) -> Mapping[str, Any]:\n   299\t        """Alias for mark.kwargs."""\n   300\t        return self.mark.kwargs\n   301\t\n   302\t    @property\n   303\t    def markname(self) -> str:\n   304\t        return self.name  # for backward-compat (2.4.1 had this attr)\n   305\t\n   306\t    def __repr__(self) -> str:\n   307\t        return "<MarkDecorator {!r}>".format(self.mark)\n   308\t\n   309\t    def with_args(self, *args: object, **kwargs: object) -> "MarkDecorator":\n   310\t        """Return a MarkDecorator with extra arguments added.\n   311\t\n   312\t        Unlike calling the MarkDecorator, with_args() can be used even\n   313\t        if the sole argument is a callable/class.\n   314\t\n   315\t        :return: MarkDecorator\n   316\t        """\n   317\t        mark = Mark(self.name, args, kwargs)\n   318\t        return self.__class__(self.mark.combined_with(mark))\n   319\t\n   320\t    # Type ignored because the overloads overlap with an incompatible\n   321\t    # return type. user response: your_thoughts_here
I'll apply a small, targeted edit to requests/sessions.py replacing the loop that removed None-valued keys from request_setting with a loop that removes keys set to None in the merged result. This will ensure session.headers['Accept-Encoding'] = None suppresses that header.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - << 'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('requests/sessions.py')
s = p.read_text()
start_marker = "    # Remove keys that are set to None."
# find start of the removal block
idx = s.find(start_marker)
if idx == -1:
    print("Start marker not found; aborting.")
    raise SystemExit(1)
# find the following 'return merged_setting' after the marker
ret_idx = s.find("    return merged_setting", idx)
if ret_idx == -1:
    print("return merged_setting not found after marker; aborting.")
    raise SystemExit(1)
# Determine end index to replace up to the end of that return line
# include the return line and the following newline
end_idx = ret_idx + len("    return merged_setting") 
# Build new replacement block
new_block = (
    "    # Remove keys that are set to None in the merged result.\n"
    "    # If a key is explicitly set to None in either the session settings\n"
    "    # or the request settings, it should be omitted from the final mapping.\n"
    "    # (This handles the common case of session.headers['Some-Header'] = None\n"
    "    # meaning \"do not send this header\".)\n"
    "    for (k, v) in list(merged_setting.items()):\n"
    "        if v is None:\n"
    "            del merged_setting[k]\n\n"
    "    return merged_setting"
)
# Replace the slice from the start_marker to the return line end with new_block
# First find the beginning of the line for start_marker to preserve indentation
line_start = s.rfind('\\n', 0, idx) + 1
new_s = s[:line_start] + new_block + s[end_idx:]
p.write_text(new_s)
print("Updated requests/sessions.py")
PY

user response: your_thoughts_here
I'll modify ContextMixin.get_context_data in django/views/generic/base.py to unwrap SimpleLazyObject values in the kwargs before returning them. This keeps the deprecation behavior (the URL-kwargs wrapped in SimpleLazyObject still warn when accessed in templates), but ensures that view code that reads values from the context kwargs (e.g. to use in ORM filters) receives the real underlying objects rather than SimpleLazyObject proxies.

I'll edit the file and produce a minimal patch.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
applypatch << 'PATCH'
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: django/views/generic/base.py
@@
     def get_context_data(self, **kwargs):
         kwargs.setdefault('view', self)
         if self.extra_context is not None:
             kwargs.update(self.extra_context)
-        return kwargs
+        # Ensure SimpleLazyObject values are resolved to their underlying
+        # objects when returning the context. URL kwargs are wrapped in
+        # SimpleLazyObject (see _wrap_url_kwargs_with_deprecation_warning),
+        # and leaving them as lazy proxies can cause unexpected type errors
+        # when view code uses those values (for example passing them to ORM
+        # filters). Force evaluation and replace the proxy with the wrapped
+        # object where possible.
+        for key, value in list(kwargs.items()):
+            if isinstance(value, SimpleLazyObject):
+                try:
+                    # Force evaluation of the lazy object. _setup will populate
+                    # _wrapped with the actual value.
+                    value._setup()
+                except Exception:
+                    # If setup fails for any reason, leave the lazy object as-is.
+                    continue
+                kwargs[key] = getattr(value, '_wrapped', value)
+        return kwargs
*** End Patch
PATCH
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----
user response: I'll modify sympy/physics/units/unitsystem.py to allow addition when the dimension system considers two Dimension objects equivalent (e.g., velocity and acceleration*time). I'll make a minimal targeted change in the Add branch of _collect_factor_and_dimension so it checks self.get_dimension_system().equivalent_dims(...) before raising an error.

Now applying the change. 
----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('sympy/physics/units/unitsystem.py')
s = p.read_text()
old = (
"            factor, dim = self._collect_factor_and_dimension(expr.args[0])\n"
"            for addend in expr.args[1:]:\n"
"                addend_factor, addend_dim = \\\n"
"                    self._collect_factor_and_dimension(addend)\n"
"                if dim != addend_dim:\n"
"                    raise ValueError(\n"
"                        'Dimension of \"{}\" is {}, '\n"
"                        'but it should be {}'.format(\n"
"                            addend, addend_dim, dim))\n"
"                factor += addend_factor\n"
"            return factor, dim\n"
)
if old not in s:
    raise SystemExit("Old snippet not found; aborting to avoid unintended edits.")
new = (
"            factor, dim = self._collect_factor_and_dimension(expr.args[0])\n"
"            for addend in expr.args[1:]:\n"
"                addend_factor, addend_dim = \\\n"
"                    self._collect_factor_and_dimension(addend)\n"
"                if dim != addend_dim:\n"
"                    # Allow addition when the dimension system considers the\n"
"                    # two dimensions equivalent (for example velocity and\n"
"                    # acceleration*time). In that case, treat them as the\n"
"                    # same dimension for the purposes of addition.\n"
"                    if self.get_dimension_system().equivalent_dims(dim, addend_dim):\n"
"                        # equivalent dimensions: proceed to add the numeric factors\n"
"                        pass\n"
"                    else:\n"
"                        raise ValueError(\n"
"                            'Dimension of \"{}\" is {}, '\n"
"                            'but it should be {}'.format(\n"
"                                addend, addend_dim, dim))\n"
"                factor += addend_factor\n"
"            return factor, dim\n"
)
s2 = s.replace(old, new)
p.write_text(s2)
print("File updated")

user response: I will update GeometryEntity.__rmul__ in sympy/geometry/entity.py so that number * Point uses Point.__mul__ (coordinate-wise multiplication) instead of producing a SymPy Mul containing the Point. I'll modify the minimal function body and stage the change.

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('sympy/geometry/entity.py')
s = p.read_text()

old_snippet_start = "    def __rmul__(self, a):\n        \"\"\"Implementation of reverse multiplication method.\"\"\"\n        return a.__mul__(self)\n"
if old_snippet_start not in s:
    print("Expected old snippet not found; aborting.")
else:
    new_snippet = """    def __rmul__(self, a):
        \"\"\"Implementation of reverse multiplication method.

        Try the left operand's __mul__ first. However, for some SymPy numeric
        types (e.g. Float, Integer) __mul__ will produce a Mul expression
        containing the GeometryEntity instead of returning NotImplemented.
        In that case we should use the GeometryEntity's own __mul__ so that
        number * Point behaves the same as Point * number (coordinate-wise
        multiplication).
        \"\"\"
        try:
            res = a.__mul__(self)
        except Exception:
            # If the left operand's __mul__ raised, fall back to entity's __mul__.
            return self.__mul__(a)

        # If left operand doesn't know how to handle it, use entity's __mul__.
        if res is NotImplemented:
            return self.__mul__(a)

        # If the left operand returned a Mul that contains this entity,
        # prefer the entity's __mul__ (e.g., 2.0*Point(...) should act like
        # Point.__mul__).
        try:
            from sympy.core.mul import Mul
            if isinstance(res, Mul) and res.has(self):
                return self.__mul__(a)
        except Exception:
            # If inspection fails for any reason, fall back to left operand's result.
            pass

        return res
"""
    s2 = s.replace(old_snippet_start, new_snippet)
    if s2 == s:
        print("Replacement did not change the file (pattern mismatch).")
    else:
        p.write_text(s2)
        print("File updated.")
PY
----END_FUNCTION_CALL----

 def _escape_pgpass(txt):
     """
     Escape a fragment of a PostgreSQL .pgpass file.
     """
     return txt.replace('\\', '\\\\').replace(':', '\\:')
 
@@
     def runshell_db(cls, conn_params):
         args = [cls.executable_name]
 
         host = conn_params.get('host', '')
         port = conn_params.get('port', '')
         dbname = conn_params.get('database', '')
         user = conn_params.get('user', '')
         passwd = conn_params.get('password', '')
 
         if user:
             args += ['-U', user]
         if host:
             args += ['-h', host]
         if port:
             args += ['-p', str(port)]
         args += [dbname]

-                        str(port) or '*',

-                    # user input the password manually.

+        # Prepare a custom environment for the subprocess so we don't need to
+        # rely on global os.environ side effects. Use PGPASSWORD if a password
+        # is provided. Keep SIGINT handling behavior (ignored in Python so it's
+        # passed to the child process).
+        env = os.environ.copy()
+        if passwd:
+            env['PGPASSWORD'] = passwd
+        sigint_handler = signal.getsignal(signal.SIGINT)
+        try:
+            # Allow SIGINT to pass to psql to abort queries.
+            signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, signal.SIG_IGN)
+            # Use subprocess.run with check=True to mirror check_call behavior
+            # while allowing us to pass a custom environment.
+            subprocess.run(args, env=env, check=True)
+        finally:
+            # Restore the original SIGINT handler.
+            signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, sigint_handler)
*** End Patch

user response: I updated sympy/physics/units/unitsystem.py to allow addition when two dimensions are considered equivalent by the active dimension system (i.e., use DimensionSystem.equivalent_dims to allow addition of equivalent but not literally-equal Dimension objects). This prevents spurious ValueError for expressions like a1*t1 + v1 where acceleration*time and velocity are equivalent.

Change summary:
- In UnitSystem._collect_factor_and_dimension, Add branch now checks self.get_dimension_system().equivalent_dims(dim, addend_dim) and permits the addition if True; otherwise it raises as before.

This is a minimal, targeted fix.

           yield resp\n   131\t\n   132\t\n   133\tclass Session(SessionRedirectMixin):\n   134\t    """A Requests session.\n   135\t\n   136\t    Provides cookie persistence, connection-pooling, and configuration.\n   137\t\n   138\t    Basic Usage::\n   139\t\n   140\t      >>> import requests\n   141\t      >>> s = requests.Session()\n   142\t      >>> s.get(\'http://httpbin.org/get\')\n   143\t      200\n   144\t    """\n   145\t\n   146\t    __attrs__ = [\n   147\t        \'headers\', \'cookies\', \'auth\', \'timeout\', \'proxies\', \'hooks\',\n   148\t        \'params\', \'verify\', \'cert\', \'prefetch\', \'adapters\', \'stream\',\n   149\t        \'trust_env\', \'max_redirects\']\n   150\t\n   151\t    def __init__(self):\n   152\t\n   153\t        #: A case-insensitive dictionary of headers to be sent on each\n   154\t        #: :class:`Request <Request>` sent from this\n   155\t        #: :class:`Session <Session>`.\n   156\t        self.headers =        self.proxies = {}\n   166\t\n   167\t        #: Event-handling hooks.\n   168\t        self.hooks = default_hooks()\n   169\t\n   170\t        #: Dictionary of querystring data to attach to By default it is a\n   193\t        #: :class:`RequestsCookieJar <requests.cookies.RequestsCookieJar>`, but\n   194\t        #: may be any other ``cookielib.CookieJar`` compatible object.\n   195\t        self.cookies = cookiejar_from_dict({})\n   196\t\n   197\t        # Default connection adapters.\n   198\t        self.adapters = OrderedDict()\n   199\t        self.mount(\'https://\', HTTPAdapter())\n   200\t        self.mount(\'http://\', HTTPAdapter())\n   201\t\n   202\t    def __enter__(self):\n   203\t        return self\n   204\t\n   205\t    def __exit__(self, *args):\n   206\t        self.close()\n   207\t\n   208\t    def prepare_request(self, request):\n   209\t        """Constructs a :class:`PreparedRequest <PreparedRequest>` for\n   210\t        transmission and returns it. The :class:`PreparedRequest` has settings\n   211\t        merged from the :class:`Request <Request>` instance and those of the\n   212\t        :class:`Session`.\n   213\t\n   214\t        :param request: :class:`Request` instance to prepare with this\n   215\t            session\'s settings.\n   216\t        """\n   217\t        cookies = request.cookies or {}\n   218\t\n   219\t        # Bootstrap CookieJar.\n   220\t        if not isinstance(cookies, cookielib.CookieJar):\n   221\t            cookies = cookiejar_from_dict(cookies)\n   222\t\n   223\t        # Merge with session authentication if not explicitly set.\n   229\t        auth = request.auth\n   230\t        if self.trust_env and not auth and not self.auth:\n   231\t            auth = get_netrc_auth(request.url)\n hooks=merge_hooks(request.hooks, self.hooks),\n   244\t        )\n   245\t        return p\n   246\t\n   247\t    def request(self, method, url,\n   248\t        params=None,\n   249\t        data=None,\n   250\t        headers=None,\n   251\t        cookies=None,\n   252\t        files=None,\n   253\t        auth=None,\n   254\t        timeout=None,\n   255\t        allow_redirects=True,\n   256\t        proxies=None,\n   257\t        hooks=None,\n   258\t        stream=None,\n   259\t        verify=None,\n   260\t        cert=None):\n   261\t        """Constructs a :class:`Request <Request>`, prepares it and sends it.\n   262\t        Returns :class:`Response <Response>` object.\n   263\t\n   264\t        :param method: method for the new :class:`Request` object.\n   265\t        :param url: URL for the new :class:`Request` object.\n   266\t        :param params: (optional) Dictionary or bytes to be sent in the query\n   267\t (optional) Dictionary of HTTP Headers to send with the\n   271\t            :class:`Request`.\n   272\t        :param cookies: (optional) Dict or CookieJar object to send with the\n   273\t            :class:`Request`.\n   274\t        :param files: (optional) Dictionary of \'filename\': file-like-objects\n   275\t            for multipart encoding upload.\n   276\t        :param auth: (optional) 280\t        :param allow_redirects: (optional) Boolean. Set to True by default.\n   281\t        :param proxies: (optional) Dictionary mapping protocol to the URL of\n   282\t            the proxy.\n   283\t        :param stream: (optional) whether to immediately download the response\n   284\t            content. Defaults to ``False``.\n   285\t        :param verify: (optional) if ``True``, the SSL cert will be verified.\n   286\t            A CA_BUNDLE path can also be provided.\n   287\t        :param cert: (optional) if String, path to ssl client cert file (.pem).\n   288\t            If Tuple, (\'cert\', \'key\') pair.\n   289\t        """\n   290\t\n   291\t        method = builtin_str(method)\n   292\t\n   293\t        # Create the Request.\n   294\t        req = Request(\n   295\t            method = method.upper(),\n   296\t            url = url,\n   297\t            headers = headers,\n   298\t            files = files,\n   299\t            data = data or {},\n   300\t            params = params or {},\n   301\t            auth = auth,\n   302\t            cookies = cookies,\n   303\t            hooks = hooks,\n   304\t        )\n   305\t        prep = self.prepare_request(req)\n   306\t\n   307\t        proxies = proxies or {}\n   308\t\n   309\t        # Gather clues from the surrounding environment.\n   310\t        if self.trust_env:\n   311\t            # Set environment\'s proxies.\n   312\t            env_proxies = get_environ_proxies(url) or {}\n   313\t            for (k, v) in env_proxies.items():\n   314\t                proxies.setdefault(k, v)\n   315\t\n   316\t            # p1 = ge.Point(0,0)

----BEGIN_FUNCTION_CALL----
run_bash_cmd
----ARG----
command
----VALUE----
python - <<'PY'
from pathlib import Path
p = Path('django/forms/models.py')
text = p.read_text()
old = (
    "        if self.field.empty_label is not None:\n"
    "            yield (\"\", self.field.empty_label)\n"
)
if old in text:
    new = (
        "        if self.field.empty_label is not None:\n"
        "            # Radio widgets have an intrinsic \"unfilled\" state (no radio selected),\n"
        "            # so rendering an explicit empty choice (e.g. \"---------\") is\n"
        "            # confusing when the field is required (model.blank is False).\n"
        "            # Avoid adding the empty choice for radio widgets when the field\n"
        "            # is required. For other widgets (e.g. <select>), keep the empty\n"
        "            # choice behavior for compatibility.\n"
        "            widget_input_type = getattr(self.field.widget, 'input_type', None)\n"
        "            if not (widget_input_type == 'radio' and self.field.required):\n"
        "                yield (\"\", self.field.empty_label)\n"
    )
    text = text.replace(old, new, 1)
    p.write_text(text)
    print("Patched django/forms/models.py")
else:
    print("Pattern not found; no changes made.")
